The CO2 electrochemistry reduction (CO2ER) to valuable chemicals is one of the attractive strategies for the utilization of greenhouse gas and carbon recovery. The catalyst for the reaction is extremely important. In the present work, a carbon matrix derived from the pyrolysis of nitrogen-rich metal triazole (MET) supported Ni-metal (denoted as Ni/CN) was developed as a catalyst for the CO2ER. A catalyst with a heteroatom chlorine introduction, named the Ni/(Cl-CN), enhanced the catalytic performances remarkably. The Ni/(Cl-CN) catalyst with the Ni loading of 4.5 wt% showed the best catalytic performance with a Faradaic efficiency of CO (FECO) over 90% in a range of −0.7 to −1.1 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M KCl solution, and the highest formation activity reached 137.1 mmol∙gcat −1·h−1. Besides, the highest total current density reached 21.4 mA cm−2 (FECO>90%) in an H-type cell at −1.1 V (vs. RHE). The catalyst was characterized by diverse technologies, and the results indicated that it contains Ni NPs and homogenous dispersed Ni sites, and both of them are active for the reaction. The introduction of Cl atom indeed promotes the catalytic performance probably via the stabilization of Ni+ species and enhances the CO2 adsorption and activation. The present work not only provides an efficient heteroatom-doped metal-NC catalyst in CO2ER to CO but also sheds light on tuning catalytic performances by doping halogen atoms. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrochemical CO2 reduction Chlorine-doping materials CO Ni-based catalyst Aqueous electrolyte Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The high concentration of CO2 in the air is one of the main reasons for environmental issues. The transformation of CO2 into value-added chemicals has attracted much attention to achieving carbon neutrality. Electrochemical CO2 reduction (CO2ER) is a promising route for utilizing CO2 resources, which can partly solve environmental and energy problems raised by the excessive utilization of fossil fuels [1,2]. Thus, especially in recent years, it has become a hot topic under the background of pursuing carbon neutrality [3–6]. Nevertheless, a higher overpotential is always required for the chemical inertness of CO2. Besides, the reaction always produces many products, including CO, CH4, CH3OH, HCOOH, C2H5OH, and C2H4, etc. [7], depending on the catalyst, electrolyte, and conditions applied. On the other hand, CO2ER could be conducted in water, ionic liquids, organic solvents, and their mixed electrolyte. Undoubtedly, water is a green solvent for the reaction. However, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) competition is still a huge challenge for CO2ER in aqueous electrolytes. Therefore, developing an efficient electrocatalyst with high selectivity and activity to CO2ER yet inhibiting HER is significantly important [8–10]. To date, many electrocatalysts have been developed for CO2ER to diverse value-add chemicals, including metal oxides, alloys, precious metals, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), and transition metals, etc. [11]. Aiming to synthesize CO, an important platform molecule for producing hydrocarbons, aldehydes, and alcohols, etc., catalysts such as Co(II)CPY/CNT [12], NiFe-DASC [13], Ag1−-N3/PCNC [14], and CoTAP[15] were well established. Although many excellent results have been achieved, most of the developed electrocatalysts still suffer from the drawbacks of lower Faradaic efficiency, high overpotential, narrow electrolytic window, and/or low current densities, etc., further limiting their applications. Thus, constructing efficient catalysts for CO synthesis is still one of the main focuses for CO2ER. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a kind of porous crystalline materials, especially as precursors/self-sacrificial templates for the preparation of metal component by pyrolysis [16,17]. Based on these MOFs, large atom utilization and special electronic structure contribute to the excellent electrochemical performance in CO2ER due to the unique local coordination environment [18]. In general, nitrogen-coordinating metal (M−Nx) moieties are often active sites in these high metal dispersion catalysts, such as M − N4, resulting in a more dominant CO2ER than HER [19,20]. Metal triazole (MET) frameworks are of nitrogen-rich MOFs with special advantages and consist of N atoms in 1H-1,2,3-triazole with octahedral coordination of divalent metal ions [21]. Compared with the most normally used zeolite-imidazole frameworks (ZIFs), METs possess special advantages, such as containing high theoretical N content (41.7%) and abundant mesopores during the pyrolysis, having a high tolerance for doping heteroatoms such as F, O, B, P, Cl, etc. These advantages, especially doping heteroatoms, could always offer a versatile microenvironment and adjust metal electronic properties. Thus, preparing a catalyst by pyrolysis of METs is a promising approach to constructing high-efficient catalysts [22]. As mentioned above, heteroatom doping could affect the catalyst properties to facilitate diverse catalytic reactions. Halide ions such as F−, Cl−, Br−, and I− play important roles in adjusting the electronic structures, coordination ability, and structural properties, etc. [23,24]. For example, the presence of I− could induce the structure change for the formation of entangled Cu nanowires [25]. Ma et al. [26]. noted fluorine-enhanced water activation, and the halogen on copper surfaces accelerated the adsorption of CO and further hydrogenated the adsorbed CO to CHO intermediates. Xie et al. [27]. developed an interlayer fluorine-doped carbon, which led to structural defects in the carbon lattice and further enhanced the CO selectivity. Similarly, Pan et al. [28]. also demonstrated that the doping of fluorine improved the performance of the nitrogen-carbon material, which showed FE stability and high current under continuous operation for 40 h. The lower electronegativity of the heteroatom favors to change the electron density of the active site, and thus enhance the D-band delocalization which makes it have a low binding strength for CO intermediate, improving the selectivity of the reaction. Herein, we developed a Cl-doping Ni-based NC material derived from MET as the precursor of NC and 4,5-dichloroimidazole (dcIm) as the Cl source via pyrolysis treatment, which was applied in catalyzing CO2ER to CO in aqueous electrolyte. The Ni species with a loading of 4.5% combined with Cl loading enhanced the catalytic performances remarkably. The catalyst provided an FECO of 98% and a current density of 10.3 mA·cm−2 at −0.90 V (hereafter, referred to RHE, reversible hydrogen electrode), and the highest formation activity reached 137.1 mmol∙gcat −1·h−1. What's more, higher than 90% of FECO can be obtained from −0.70 to −1.10 V, and the catalyst possesses a wider potential window than the reported catalysts in Table S1. Characterization results indicated the presence of Cl could improve the CO2 adsorption capacity in carbonaceous materials. The present work offers an efficient catalyst for the CO2ER to CO, and the strategy for constructing a Cl-doping Ni/NC catalyst provides some new insights into preparing other halide elements modified metal catalysts and understanding their roles in reactions. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Characterization The Cl-modified Ni/NC catalysts were prepared by coordination and calcination methods. Scheme 1 shows the preparation procedures for the catalysts, and the details for the preparation are given in supporting information. Initially, an Ni-doped MOF, i.e., the Ni-MET(Zn)-dcIm was prepared from the coordination of MET(Zn)-dcIm and NiCl2. The obtained Ni-doped MOF was pyrolyzed at 900 °C for 2 h in an Ar gas, followed by treatment at 700 °C for 20 min in NH3 flow, and finally, the Cl-modified Ni/NC catalyst was obtained and marked as Ni/(Cl-NC)-X, where X is the amount of Ni loading. The ammoniation under NH3 could offer a high N amount. Typically, the Ni/(Cl-NC)-1, Ni/(Cl-NC)-2, and Ni/(Cl-NC)-3 catalysts mean that the Ni loading amounts are 0.19%, 4.54%, and 9.17%, respectively, which were detected by ICP-OES (Table S2). The morphologies of the prepared Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalysts were analyzed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. 1 a and b, it possesses a thin layer nanostructure, and Ni NPs exist in the catalyst (Fig. 1c). Moreover, the lattice spacing of nanoparticle of 0.204 nm in the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image could be assigned to the Ni (111) crystal planes (Figs. 1d and S1). The element mapping analysis identified that C, N, and Cl elements are uniformly distributed over the whole catalyst, confirming that the N and Cl elements were successfully doped on the catalyst (Figs. 1e, S2, and Table S2). However, as for Ni atoms, they exist both in the forms of uniform dispersion and aggregation in nanoparticles (Fig. 1g). The Cl doping amount was approximate 0.35% from the EDS spectrum (Fig. S2), which was consistent with the potentiometric titration result of 0.39 wt%. The N2 adsorption–desorption measurements were used to estimate the textural and structural properties of the prepared Ni/(Cl-NC)-X samples. Fig. S3 showed the isotherms and BJH pore size distribution curves, and the calculated results are collected in Table 1 . The Ni/(Cl-NC)-X exhibited mesoporous adsorption characteristics. Accordingly, both the Ni/(Cl-NC)-1 and the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 exhibit a higher Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (Table 1). Particularly, the Ni/(Cl-NC)-1 exhibits the largest BET surface area of 880 m2 g−1 and the biggest total pore volume of 1.97 cm3/g. The pyrolyzed MET(Zn)-dcIm and Ni/(NC) have similar preparation methods but different textural properties, indicating that they possessed different structures. In the three Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts, the Ni/(Cl-NC)-3 showed the lowest BET surface area, total pore volume, and pore size, and this was presumably due to the high loading of Ni NPs blocking the holes. The pore size distribution curves show the presence of a large number of mesopores in the range of 4∼15 nm for the Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts (Fig. S3b). The results indicated that a suitable amount of Ni can induce the formation of mesopores, which was presumably due to the aggregation of Ni species to NPs causing the formation of the local pores during the pyrolysis. The mesopores with large pore volume and high specific surface area on the Ni/(Cl-NC)-1 and Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalysts not only are advantaged to electron transfer and mass diffusion but also facilitate the adsorption of CO2 [29]. Compared with the Ni/(NC) catalyst, the Ni/(Cl-NC)-1 possessed the highest pore volume, which has advantage on the mass transfer in the reaction (Fig. S3b). Raman spectra were conducted to study the surface information of the as-prepared catalysts, with the results given in Fig. 2 a. All samples show typical D and G bands at 1350 cm−1 and 1583 cm−1, respectively. In general, the D band is put down to disordered structure and structural defects, while the G band is connected with the E2g vibrational mode of the sp2 bonded graphitic carbons. ID/IG is widely applied to evaluate the density of defects in carbon-based materials, and the higher the ID/IG ratio means the higher degree of defects in carbon materials. Benefiting from the ability of those defects to effectively adjust the charge distribution and surface adsorption of the catalyst, the C=O bonds of CO2 are further activated [30–32]. The ID/IG ratios are 1.26 and 1.00 for the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 and Ni/(NC)-1, respectively, although their Ni loading amounts were both approximately 4.5wt% (Table S2). The results indicated the doping of chlorine causes a higher degree of structural disorder, which will promote the adsorption of CO2 molecules and promote the CO2ER. The Ni/(Cl-NC)-3 got the highest ID/IG value of 1.28, indicative of the existence of larger structural defects. Combined with the following activity study, it showed a relatively low FECO probably for the low selectivity. Excessive metal loading could lead to severe hydrogen evolution and reduce the FECO. Therefore, the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst is an optimized catalyst with a suitable Ni loading amount of 4.5%. These results indicated that doping Ni on the carbon matrix also causes the increase of carbon disorder degree, resulting in more structural defects. This is advantageous for obtaining a large number of active sites to improve CO2ER performance [33,34]. Raman spectra with a high ratio of ID/IG indicate a defect-rich structure of these Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts, which is consistent with the broad carbon peak as measured in the XRD pattern in Fig. 2b [35]. Furthermore, the diffraction peaks for Ni0 were observed for the Ni/(Cl-NC)-X and Ni/(NC) catalysts. With an increase of Ni components, the typical Ni0 crystalline peaks at 44.5, 51.8, and 76.5° in the XRD spectra of the samples were observed (PDF#87–0712), indicating the formation of Ni NPs in the Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts [36]. The surface composition of the Ni/(NC) and Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and the results are given in Figs. 3 and S4. As demonstrated in Fig. S4, the XPS spectra of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts confirm the existence of Ni, O, N, and C elements. The Cl XPS spectra of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts supported the existence of the Cl element in these catalysts. For the Ni/(Cl-NC)-3 catalyst, a fitted peak at 198.0 eV could be assigned to Cl− of Ni-Cl species, while the peaks at 200.4 eV and 202.0 eV were attributed to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 XPS peaks of CCl species, respectively [37]. The presence of the C−Cl bond induces a local electronic distribution for the high electronegativity of Cl, further facilitating O2 activation [38]. For comparison, the Ni/(NC) has no peak of Cl species (Fig. S5), confirming that the Cl element was successfully doped into the Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts. The type of N species of all tested samples is similar but with different intensities. According to the study, the peak at 400.9 eV in Fig. 3b is graphite-N, whose affinity for CO2 makes it favorable for the activation of CO2 [39]. The fitted peaks at 399.4, 398.1, and 398.7 eV were assigned to pyrrolic-N, pyridinic-N, and Ni–N, respectively. With an increase of Ni content in the Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts, the pyrrolic-N content did not change significantly. However, the pyrrolic-N content in the Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts is slightly increased compared with that of Ni/(NC). The Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst has the highest pyrrolic-N content of 22.3% (Table S2), and contains a large amount of pyrrole-N. The presence of pyrrolic-N not only inhibits the occurrence of HER but also effectively reduces the reaction energy barrier of CO2ER [40]. Correspondingly, the Ni/(Cl-NC)-3 catalyst exhibited the lowest pyrrolic-N content and probably provided a high HER activity. The N atoms were originated from the metal triazole framework and NH3 ammonization. The Ni 2P3/2 XPS spectra of all catalysts were split into the metallic Ni0 (853.2 eV), Ni+ (854.7 eV), and Ni2+ (855.8 eV) [39,40], respectively, indicative of the presence of multivalent Ni in these Ni/(Cl-NC)-X samples. Furthermore, the Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts showed more Ni+ species compared with that of Ni/(NC) (Fig. 3c). It is proved that the doping of chlorine could regulate the valence state of Ni species. The relative peak areas in high-resolution XPS were used to evaluate the contents of Ni+ in the prepared Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts. The result reveals that the Ni+ ratio of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 was about 28%, which was the highest among the prepared catalysts. The Ni/(Cl-NC)-3 shows a peak of metallic Ni0 because of the high content of Ni NPs (Fig. 3c). These results further demonstrated that the appropriate N content of Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalysts facilitate the formation of abundant Ni+ active sites, which then modulate the surface electronic structures of Ni species. Fig. 3d showed the three main peaks of the C 1s spectra, corresponding to C sp3 of -C=O at 287.9 eV, C sp3 peak of C−N and C−O at 285.7 eV, and C sp2 peak of C−C/C=C at 284.4 eV, respectively. The relative percentage of these carbon species in the prepared Ni/(Cl-NC)-X samples has high relationships with the Ni concentrations. As the Ni concentration increases from 0.19% of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-1 to 9.17% of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-3, the content of C−C/C=C species increases from 35% to 56%, suggesting that the concentration of Ni can change the degree of graphitization. The graphitization degree of the catalyst are related with the Ni loadings, which was proabably due to the Ni species act as catalysts for the graphitization. Compared with the Ni/(Cl-NC)-1, the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst has a higher degree of graphitization, which could offer higher electrical conductivity and thus benefit their electrocatalytic performances in the reaction. 2.2 Electrocatalytic performances of the CO2ER The electrochemical activity of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 sample was preliminarily studied by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) in CO2 or Ar saturated KCl electrolyte (0.1 M). As exhibited in Fig. 4 a, compared with the current density in CO2 saturated electrolyte, the current density obtained in the Ar saturated is much lower, confirming that the CO2ER occurs in CO2 saturated electrolyte [41]. Besides, the current density increased rapidly with increasingly negative potentials in CO2 saturated electrolyte, indicating that the CO2 reduction activity of Ni-catalyst was greater than that of H2O [42]. Moreover, compared with the other tested catalysts, the current density of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst is the second highest, suggesting that uniform doping of heteroatoms and hierarchically porous nitrogen-doped carbon matrix are beneficial for improving activity (Fig. S6). The Ni/(Cl-NC)-3 showed the highest current density but a relatively high selectivity of HER. Upon reaction completion, the collected gas and electrolyte were analyzed by GC and 1H NMR, and these spectra obtained over the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst at −0.9 V are given in Figs. S7 and S8. The results demonstrated that the reaction in CO2-saturated electrolyte only produced CO and H2. The dependence of FECO on the applied potential over the Ni/NC and Ni/(Cl-NC)-X samples for the CO2ER was calculated, and the results are summarized in Figs. 4b and S9. Like the other Ni-based catalysts reported in Table S1, all the present Ni/(Cl-NC)-X catalysts also produced consistent reduction products. CO is the main product of CO2ER, while H2 is the competitive product. Fig. 4b also demonstrates that the FECO obtained over the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst is higher than 90% in the potential range of −0.7 V to −1.1 V, indicating that the present catalyst works well in a wide potential window. Compared with the Ni/(NC) catalyst with Cl-free, the Cl-doped Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst shows much superior catalytic performance, verifying that the Cl doping enhances the activity remarkably. Besides, the doping of highly dispersed heteroatomic chlorine not only improves the activity of the reaction but also broadens the active window. Therefore, we could conclude that the addition of Cl atoms indeed promotes the catalytic performances of the Ni-based electrocatalyst. The Ni/(Cl-NC)-3 shows relatively lower performances in CO2ER due to the presence of large amounts of Ni NPs, which are unfavorable for the high selectivity of CO generation. This was probably due to the high loading catalyst possesses bigger size of Ni particles, which further improves the conductivity of the catalyst but reduces the FECO. Besides, to find out the role of Ni species in the reaction, we conducted a poison experiment by adding KSCN into the electrolyte, and the results are given in Fig. S10. The result confirmed that the Ni species were poisoned by KSCN, indicating that the Ni NPs are the active sites or the part active sites for the reaction. The residual FECO was probably contributed from the Ni species coated by the block effect of the NC shell [43]. As increasing in current density provided in Figs. 4c and S6 further confirm that the introduction of heteroatom Cl and porous nitrogen-doped carbon matrix on the electrocatalyst could enhance the catalytic performance. When the electrolytic potential is −0.9 V, the total current density of Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 is 10.3 mA cm−2, the partial current density for CO is 9.0 mA cm−2, and the highest formation activity reached 137.1 mmol∙gcat −1·h−1. In contrast, the total current density of the Ni/(NC) catalyst is only 7.6 mA cm−2, and the corresponding partial current density is 5.6 mA cm−2. As shown in Fig. 4d, the results of the continuous electrolysis tests at −0.9 V confirmed the stability of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 electrocatalyst. The current density is 10.0 mA cm−2 and remains stable, and FECO is higher than 90% in 20 h without significant decay. To discover the changes of the used catalyst, we characterized the catalyst after use for 25 h via TEM, XRD, and tested the Ni leaching in the electrolyte by ICP-OES. The TEM images indicated that there are some big particles (Fig. S11), probably due to the in-situ electro-reduction of Ni+δ to Ni0. However, the XRD of the used catalyst is similar to the fresh one, which showed the peaks contributed to Ni0 species (Fig. S12). The electrolytes after reaction were also tested to discover the Ni concentration leached from the catalysts via ICP-OES. The Ni concentration of 225 ug/L were found, which is only 0.2% of the Ni loading. Such a small amount of Ni leaching was probable not the main reason for the loss in activity in the long-term study. However, the reduction and aggregation of Ni species to Ni0 NPs were probably the reasons for the loss in activity. Indeed, the catalytic performances are affected by various factors, such as CO2 adsorption, graphitization degree, metal loading, particle size, conductivity, etc. All these factors work together to affect the catalytic performances. Despite the Ni/(Cl-CN)-2 do not show the best performance in CO2 adsorption tests and graphitization degree, it showed the highest activity than the other compared catalysts. To further confirm the active site of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst, it was treated with HCl solution (pH = 2) to corrode the Ni NPs but kept the single Ni atoms [44]. Compared with the untreated catalyst, the FECO over the treated one decreased remarkably, finding the presence of Ni NPs was more favorable for the formation of CO (Fig. S13), which was confirmed by most of the reported Ni-based electrocatalysts [39,45]. The FECO and partial current densities (j co) on the MET(Zn)-dcIm are very low, as shown in Fig. 4b and 4c, indicating that the electrocatalytic activity of the MET(Zn)-dcIm is very poor and negligible. Furthermore, heteroatomic chlorine has a special electronic property that modulates the surrounding electronic structure. This property helps to trap the active metal species to form new coordination sites as active species [46]. Therefore, the superior catalytic performance of Ni/(NC)-2 compared with that of Ni/(Cl-NC) is due to the presence of some special active sites after chlorine doping. The electrolyte affects the catalytic performances remarkably, which could tune the pH, conductivity, and local coordination effect between the electrode and ion [47]. Thus, we conducted CO2ER over the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst in diverse electrolytes, and their performances are given in Fig. 5 a. In K+ salt electrolytes (0.1 mol/L), at −0.9 V, the FECO obtained on the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst followed the order of KCl > KOH >K2SO4 > KHCO3 > KH2PO4. The KCl electrolyte is beneficial to the reaction, probably because HCO3 − and H2PO4 − are easily neutralized by OH− generated in situ at the catalyst/electrolyte interface, while Cl− cannot be neutralized. The increase of alkalinity near the electrode caused by the accumulation of OH− generated inhibited HER [48]. Besides, the presence of Cl could coordinate with the catalyst. In addition, we found that the reaction could achieve the highest FECO in 0.1 M KCl electrolyte by screening the KCl concentrations (Fig. 5b). 2.3 Reaction mechanisms Tafel slope analysis could offer important kinetical information about the reaction mechanism, and the results are given in Fig. 6 a. The Tafel slope value of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst is 112 mV dec−1, which is close to the theoretical 118 mV dec−1, revealing that a single electron transfer is a rate determining step (RDS) of CO2ER on the cathode catalyst [49]. To be more specific, due to the transfer of an electron and proton pair to CO2, surface adsorbed COOH* is produced [50,51]. Then, following the electron-proton pair transfer step, the adsorbed COOH* is converted into CO. Also, the Tafel slope of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 was lower than that of the Ni/(NC) (125 mV dec−1), further indicating that the introduced Cl element cooperatively works with Ni species to achieve CO2 activation. The double-layer capacitance (Cdl) (Fig. 6b) was also tested for estimating the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of all electrocatalysts. The results demonstrated the remarkably enhanced activity over the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 derived from its increased ECSA, which provides a larger number of active sites. Moreover, the CO2 adsorption capacity is vital for the catalyst. Both the larger BET surface area and more active sites exposure of this catalyst contribute to the enhanced CO2 adsorption capacity and further activation of CO2. As shown by the results of the CO2 isothermal adsorption experiment in Fig. 6c, the CO2 adsorption capacities of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-1 and Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 are significantly higher than that of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-3. It is particularly noteworthy that further catalytic conversion of CO2 is hindered due to the formation of excess metallic Ni nanoclusters, which reduces the BET specific surface area and thus adversely affects CO2 adsorption. In addition, the Ni/(NC) catalyst also has better CO2 adsorption capacity, but its activity is much lower than that of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2. This confirms that the catalyst doped with heteroatom chlorine improves the activity by changing the chemical environment of the active site but not by adjusting the pore size. Indeed, the Ni/(CN) and Ni/(CI-CN)-2 catalysts possess similar Ni loadings, but with different conductivities. This is because the latter catalyst contains Cl atoms, which could form CCl bond during the catalyst preparation. The CCl bond with high polarity, could induce the charge transformation and promote the activation of CO2. In this aspect, the Cl-doped catalyst has a priority. Compared with the Ni/(Cl-NC)-1, the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst showed a lower CO2 adsorption ability, but offered a higher catalytic performances in the present CO2ER. The Ni species are the main active site for the reaction, and confirms the results of the former poisoning experiment. The results showed the order of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS, Fig. 6d) for the tested samples are consistent with their current density curves in Fig. 4c. With an increase of Ni doping amount, the resistance decreases, while the conductivity and the current density increase. Besides, the doping of chlorine is less linked to the conductivity of the catalyst, confirming that the conductivity and charge transfer rate of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 can be further improved due to the presence of a few Ni NPs. This because that the Ni NPs can act as electron trapping centers, ensuring efficient carrier transport and high charge density [52,53]. Based on previous reports [22,40,42,54], a possible reaction mechanism of electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO over the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst was proposed. Benefiting from the superior CO2 adsorption capacity of the MET(Zn)-dcIm (Fig. 6a), a large amount of hydrated CO2 is adsorbed on the surface of the prepared catalyst. Then, thanks to the good electrical conductivity of the MET(Zn)-dclm matrix, electrons are rapidly transferred from the working electrode to the adsorbed CO2 (ads), which is converted to *CO2 •− through one-electron transfer. At the same time, a proton is transferred to *CO2 •− to form *COOH. Then, the Ni active site of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst facilitates the formed *COOH accepting electrons and protons. The generated *CO is further desorbed to CO [55]. Eventually, the surface of the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 catalyst recovers. In this way, the Metal-Triazolate-Framework catalysts modified by doping with chlorine are boosting electrocatalytic activity for CO2 to CO. 3 Conclusions In summary, the Cl-doped Metal-Triazolate-Framework was fabricated and applied as the precursor of the Ni/(Cl-N-C)-2 catalyst in electrochemical reduction of CO2 to CO in 0.1 M KCl electrolyte. The formation of covalent CCl bonds induces electron redistribution in CCl and regulates the electronegativity of the active site of the catalyst. Thus, the abilities of CO2 adsorption and activation are greatly enhanced, exhibiting outstanding CO2ER activity. The Cl modified Ni-based catalyst, i.e., the Ni/(Cl-NC)-2 enables a high FECO of 98% at −0.9 V, much outperforming the Ni/(NC) without Cl-doping. This work proves the significance of the dopant's electronegativity in nitrogen-doped carbonaceous materials and provides a new method of heteroatom-doped Mental-NC electrocatalyst in the CO2ER. coredata.dc:description: The CO2 electrochemistry reduction (CO2ER) to valuable chemicals is one of the attractive strategies for the utilization of greenhouse gas and carbon recovery. The catalyst for the reaction is extremely important. In the present work, a carbon matrix derived from the pyrolysis of nitrogen-rich metal triazole (MET) supported Ni-metal (denoted as Ni/CN) was developed as a catalyst for the CO2ER. A catalyst with a heteroatom chlorine introduction, named the Ni/(Cl-CN), enhanced the catalytic performances remarkably. The Ni/(Cl-CN) catalyst with the Ni loading of 4.5 wt% showed the best catalytic performance with a Faradaic efficiency of CO (FECO) over 90% in a range of −0.7 to −1.1 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M KCl solution, and the highest formation activity reached 137.1 mmol∙gcat −1·h−1. Besides, the highest total current density reached 21.4 mA cm−2 (FECO>90%) in an H-type cell at −1.1 V (vs. RHE). The catalyst was characterized by diverse technologies, and the results indicated that it contains Ni NPs and homogenous dispersed Ni sites, and both of them are active for the reaction. The introduction of Cl atom indeed promotes the catalytic performance probably via the stabilization of Ni+ species and enhances the CO2 adsorption and activation. The present work not only provides an efficient heteroatom-doped metal-NC catalyst in CO2ER to CO but also sheds light on tuning catalytic performances by doping halogen atoms.
coredata.dc:title: Boosting electrocatalytic CO2 reduction over Ni/CN catalysts derived from metal-triazolate-framework by doping with chlorine
